p: Brain damage: the simplest forms are anosmia and taste loss, which fortunately mostly regress: damage to the cranial nerves, especially the olfactory with infection of the olfactory lobe; damage to the thalamus and brain stem. These lesions may also be the consequence of thromboembolic syndrome or cerebral anoxia related to acute respiratory failure. There are also cerebral lesions detected by electroencephalography, which sometimes determine a frontal syndrome with cognitive disorders and memory loss. These disorders will require a long rehabilitation. More exceptionally, acute encephalitis leading to rapid death has been described.
